text: Patient: Sure. Doctor: And during that time you’re more tired is when your blood counts are low when you’re fighting infection. So we ask you not to travel on a plane those four days, if at all possible. If you do you have to wear a mask, and we ask you not to be around babies for those four days if possible because they’re infectious, not that you’re an injury to them. Patient: Right. Doctor: But other than that uh there really are no side effects. You may lose your hair temporarily. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, um, but it grows back. Um and you generally will only lose it for the last two doses. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So for about a month and a half you may have a hair problem. But that’s it. Patient: No long-term neuropathy or anything that? Doctor: Not, okay, so not with the four doses and uh not the way we give it because we really have tons you know of experience and we know how to give it, quite frankly. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you went to the community, they give you six doses really high, and you would end up with neuropathy that’s pretty severe. Patient: Okay, um. Is there any detriment to having the chemo before the radiation?

text: Family Member: Right. Doctor: Yeah. I hope that’s true. But my experience with these really expensive drugs is you’re going to get billed. Patient: Right. I was thinking the same thing. Doctor: Okay? So they will ask you then at our pharmacy, well, can you afford that amount of money, and if you can’t, so they will work to see if there’s grants to see whether they can, the drug companies who make these drugs, can cover the cost that you can’t cover. Okay? But you have to have Medicare D and all these other things. So it can take a little bit while depending on if they have it. And again, they’re going to do a wallet check to see how much you make to see what they think you can cover. Patient: Well, I’m working. Family Member: Well, right. Doctor: That, that’s just the rules that they’re going to go through. Family Member: I see. Doctor: Abiraterone is probably what I would prefer. Although for you, the downsides of it is potentially, you know, fluid retention. Huh, there is a lot of fatigue related to it. Huh, huh, we have to watch your blood tests a little bit. Huh, about seventy-five percent, three out of four people, their PSA is going to drop on it. Huh, the average person’s on it for about fifteen months, then the cancer figures it out, and we have to look at maybe moving to something else. We don’t change therapy based on PSA. We base it on how you’re feeling and whether your scans show more cancer than what we saw today. Okay? Patient: Now, what would you recommend right now? Doctor: Yeah. I, I like the abiraterone but we’ll have to check to sort of see what the cost is to you. The other one doesn’t need prednisone. It makes people a little bit more frail so I’m a little bit more worried about that one in you. Huh, you know, we don’t have right offhand a clinical trial that I can think about. Our first study with abiraterone, you have to have a mutation which you don’t have. So we would just be able to give you abiraterone. Our enzalutamide plus new drug first-line study is on hold right now. Huh, the two other studies that we have all require that you have had abiraterone or enzalutamide. Huh, so usually after one of these drugs if your cancer is getting worse more options from a clinical trial perspective open up. Huh, we just finished our study of radiation and a vaccine. We don’t know if that has any activity or working yet to see whether or not, huh, that would be a standard option. Huh, you aren’t eligible, so right now, it would be the abiraterone that we would head towards. So what I typically do is send an email to our pharmacy saying can you price this out, then speak to you about whether you can afford it or not afford it, and then, huh, they work on sort of the patient assistance program, if you need it. Huh, if you don’t need it or you get one of those things, then they can provide the drug. Huh, we might have you come in and meet with that pharmacist or one of the nurse practitioners that I work with, huh, to sort of just re-go over what you may feel with starting the new drug, or that if, again, we just can’t get it for you, we can try the other one, or we would think maybe even going to the radium, which is a liquid radiation drug, which is given here in the clinic. Usually that’s what we go to next. Patient: That’s what I had before but they, radia, huh- Doctor: Rad.

text: Patient: The body reacts- Family Member: Why would it do that? Doctor: Uh, because basically the medicine is, uh, a protein your body makes and just fools the brain into thinking that there’s too much testosterone, uh, and sort of tells the testicles, “Stop making testosterone.” But that which is there gets released. Family Member: Ahhh. Doctor: And so you just get a surge. And so, Family Member: Ahh. Patient: So, you’re, you’re trying to drive the level, the level down so when the surge happens, it doesn’t peak, or it peaks as low as it - Family Member: Okay. Patient: Yay. text: Family Member: Not for now. Okay. That’s good news. Doctor: You know, but someday maybe. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, it is an effective thing we use, but I think we have other things to try before. Family Member: Awesome. (sighs) Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. So, are we, or why, are we trying these other things because - and it could be both answers - because you want to know? Or because, they’re the most effective options for me? Doctor: So. (Pause) Patient: I don’t want to compromise your ethical considerations. Doctor: So, in the realm of standard treatment, the two treatments that we have that are new hormonal treatments, we call them “Second Line Treatments.” So, the, the Lupron/Eligard is the first one. We would add a second one. Both of those have been tested in big clinical trials, and both of those showed an improvement in survival for a large group of men. It wasn’t a huge improvement. Um. But it reduced your risk of dying of prostate cancer by about thirty percent. The survival improvement was on the order of months, but that is really, uh, for the whole group. It’s hard to call the individuals outta that. Um, so that’s kind of the baseline that we know. Um. And, those drugs, you know, they have side effects that we need to manage, but that’s kind of would be the next treatment that’s standard treatment. It’s approved by the FDA because of the survival improvement. The new finding about this new drug, they’re called “PARP” inhibitors. A group did a study in England where they had fifty guys who had some DNA mutation, mostly BRCA2. They treated the fifty guys; sixteen had mutations. And, they found that none of the people without the mutations responded. Fourteen of the sixteen - so, you know, ninety percent who had a mutation responded to these drugs very well. Suggesting, they’re probably going to work really well in patients like that. Um. Patient: Am I one of those people? Doctor: Yeah, you’re one of those people. Now, that drug hasn’t been through the big paces of FDA trial approval. That’s where it is right now. So, the trials we’re looking at are looking at giving that drug alone or in combination with these standard hormones. So, the trial that I would consider for you have multiple arms. We could talk about that in detail, but, it’s there’s two different trials they could either combine the drugs or give you one drug. Um. But, the, but the, where the field is moving is there’s going to be fifty trials of this to try to nail this down.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
